p: Identifying data for comparison of adaptation across countries remains a significant challenge for tracking adaptation across nations [ 18, 19]. Data on adaptation are difficult to find, and thus we must rely on the reporting of adaptation as the best option currently available for systematic analysis [ 19, 64]. Reporting of adaptation in itself is one of several important proxies for prioritisation of adaptation and adaptive capacity [ 28, 57, 64]. In this research we are searching for adaptation activities that are framed by the responsible authority as adaptation to climate change. Limited reporting may hinder sharing of experiences and best practices, learning, transparency, and effective monitoring and evaluation [ 19, 28, 72, 73]. Accordingly, in this paper we are comparing reporting of actions, rather than comparing actions per se, consistent with work assessing policy progress for other health issues [ 74, 75].
